awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Grassland Sensitivity to Climate Change at Local to Regional Scales: Assessing the Role of Ecosystem Attributes vs. Environmental Context
awd_abstract_narration:
Although scientists have learned much in the past 20 years about how individual ecosystems are likely to respond to climate change, extending this knowledge to regional and continental scales has been a far greater challenge. At these larger spatial scales, both the environment and the attributes of ecosystems vary dramatically. For example, in the central US, there are strong temperature and rainfall gradients from Texas to North Dakota and the dry plains of Colorado to eastern Kansas, and the types of grasslands differ as well (from short grasslands in the west to tall grasslands in the east). In order to better forecast how entire regions will respond to expected climatic changes, there is a pressing need to understand why ecosystems differ in their sensitivity to changes in climate.  This project includes research designed to answer a question of fundamental importance for advancing knowledge of biological processes at large scales:  How important are the attributes of ecosystems per se vs. the environmental context in which climate is changing in determining ecological responses to climate change at regional scales?  To answer this question, a geographically distributed field experiment will be conducted at six sites in NM, CO, WY and KS and the results from this experiment will be used to strengthen an existing process-based terrestrial ecosystem model. With this model, the relative importance of ecosystem attributes versus the environment for determining responses to climate change will be evaluated and then scaling rules for extending site-based knowledge to regional scales will be developed.  The experiment imposed will be a severe multi-year drought in grasslands arrayed along a rainfall gradient (from desert grassland to mesic tallgrass prairie).  Key responses measured will include many related to carbon cycling and budgets and plant biodiversity. 

The project has a number of broader impacts including enhancing existing terrestrial ecosystem modeling approaches, and conducting a field experiment that will provide a platform for others in the scientific community to conduct additional research activities.  A project website will make products (datasets, key results, papers, models) available to the scientific community and general public. Research will occur on federal lands and at a number of other research stations where outreach programs are in place, allowing results to be shared with a wide range of stakeholders.  The project is also designed to provide training opportunities for numerous graduate and undergraduate students. Because this study is unique in its spatial extent and combination of field and modeling approaches, the collaborative training opportunities available to students differs substantially from traditional degree programs.

por.por_cntn:
Future climate will be characterized by increased frequency and intensity of extreme events, such as severe droughts. These unprecedented climate extremes will impact ecosystem functioning and services. However, our understanding of grassland sensitivity to climate change at regional scale remains limited. This project was aimed to model the effects of extreme drought on grassland ecosystem carbon (C) cycling, to disentangle the effects of abiotic and biotic factors on drought sensitivity, and to scale up site-level drought sensitivity to regional level. We first conducted a data synthesis across multiple ecosystems and a modeling analysis with a process-based ecosystem model, the Terrestrial Ecosystem Model (TECO model), to examine the impacts of extreme drought on ecosystem C cycle. Both our data synthesis and modeling analysis showed that ecosystem production in grassland ecosystems was more sensitive to extreme drought than respiration because production responded directly to drought, but respiration was regulated by drought induced reduction in soil water content, reduced carbon input and gradual decrease in soil carbon pool. We then developed data assimilation algorithms to assimilate the field measurement data collected at six sites in this project to constrain parameters in the TECO model. The calibrated TECO model was then used to simulate grassland C cycling at regional scale. We found that net primary production (NPP) across grasslands was strongly correlated with mean annual precipitation, while carbon residence time was a function of mean annual temperature. Intermediates between extremes in moisture and temperature had low carbon storage potential (Xp), indicating that ecosystem C in these systems may be buffered against global change impacts on carbon storage capacity (Xc). Hot and dry grasslands had highest Xp due to both small C inputs through NPP and high C turnover rates during periods of favorable soil conditions. Overall, our findings provide insight for feedback between grassland ecosystems and climate system and therefore, have important implications for mitigating climate change. Our results also suggested that both hot, dry ecosystems and those frequently burned are vulnerable to lose C stored in these systems. Therefore, land managers and policy makers should be careful in their decisions to prevent losses of C from these ecosystems in order to mitigate climate change.

 

The on-line platform for data assimilation used in this project, EcoPAD (Ecological Platform for Assimilation of Data), is open to public use (http://www2.nau.edu/luo-lab/?ecopad). Researchers can use it for free to run their own data with different options of models and data assimilation methods.

 

In addition, we published 16 papers in peer-reviewed journals and 1 book chapter and gave 6 presentations at influential professional meetings. Through this project, we trained two postdoctoral research scientists and one graduate student to conduct data synthesis and modeling studies via data assimilation technique, as well as scientific writing and presentations.
